This is an example of splitting hairs.  You can find variation in the methods and populations of any trial.  But for any study you can say "different population" because you're never going to be working on exactly the same people as were in the study.  Sometimes changes are relevant; but here the difference is tenuous.

There are two rather different metrics most people care about: (1) what happens to me and (2) what effect does it have on the conditions around me - mask, lockdown, etc.
It is actually harder to get the answers to the first (too many variables to take into account) than to the second. We can see how deaths respond to community vaccination levels, remembering the vaccines are not very effective in the first couple of weeks after a dose, that some vaccines are designed for two doses, and that deaths lag cases by an indefinite amount ranging from most of a week to months, with a best guess point of two or three weeks. If you google "covid death chart uk", for example, you get a page that displays death records (and has a drop-down for selecting a case record in the upper left of the chart), and also a chart showing percent vaccinated (single and fully) since the vaccination began.
In the UK, like many countries in the northern hemisphere, there was a sharp peak in January, with a 7-day avg of 1248 deaths per day on January 23, and from there it dropped monotonically to the May 21 value of 6 deaths... a 99.5% decrease in deaths for a 56% vaccinated populace. 3 weeks ago the vaccination figure was 51%. Another way of looking at the COVID death rate is that the last time it was that low was March 15, 2020... 9 days after the first COVID death was recorded in the UK.
My own observation, looking at a number of countries, is that 2-3 weeks after the population reaches 45% "at least one dose" the epidemic in that country fades fast.

1st, if there is no standard on how to calculate, then it literally means nothing.

2nd, anyone who knows even the most basic concepts of statistics and probability knows that you can't express an extrapolation based on a sample by the mean, instead you'll need a range representative of your chosen level of confidence.

So, whoever chose to release information this way either doesn't understand what they're doing or are being misleading on purpose.

For the record, that 21,000 person per group size is absolutely enormous compared to other vaccines that most people consider perfectly safe.

Annual flu vaccines typically have a few hundred per group. Look around on ClinicalTrials.Gov for influenza filtering by phase 3 trials (link below). You'll find hundreds of studies like Nitazoxanide (2018) with 516 per group; FluVac (2020) with 408 per group; or Torlak-300 (2016) with a 320/160 split.

That's a big part of the reason that the covid vaccine was able to be evaluated for safety so quickly. They waited until 100ish people divided between the two groups got sick and compared the ratios there. We could test almost any vaccine that quickly using the same strategy, it's just way more expensive to give 40,000 people $200 each to volunteer for a trial so drug companies typically don't do it that way.

https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/results?cond=Influenza&term=&type=Intr&rslt=&age_v=&gndr=&intr=&titles=&outc=&spons=&lead=&id=&cntry=&state=&city=&dist=&locn=&phase=2&rsub=&strd_s=&strd_e=&prcd_s=&prcd_e=&sfpd_s=&sfpd_e=&rfpd_s=&rfpd_e=&lupd_s=&lupd_e=&sort=

This video is a public service. The 95% efficacy rate in the Pfizer trial makes it sound like, out of 21,000 participants, 1050 got sick when, in fact, only eight did (at least by the criteria set out by Pfizer—probably a few more were asymptomatic infections which Pfizer’s criteria excluded).

In the real world, as of 26 April, more than 95 million people in the United States had been fully vaccinated against COVID-19 and there were 9,245 breakthrough infections or about one-hundredth of one percent — and more than a quarter of those were asymptomatic infections.

What's the point of the parameter if it is completely meaningless?  Wholly unsatisfying video..  Scientists:  "Let's create a parameter that means nothing and cannot be used to compare anything, and make it the bedrock of reporting vaccine trial results"

"we can't compare" the numbers is strictly true; we do not have access to the missing data we would need to normalize the three trials' numbers.  For example, if we knew the strains and locations and cases that weren't counted, we could re-create a data set that would model how study A would have looked given study B's methods, but we don't know all that.  But I think practically, "we can't compare" is an oversimplification.  It's all we've got to go on, and a complicated, partially erroneous rationale is better than no rationale at all.  It's not rational to ignore your one and only data point as if your outcome is purely chance, all three ways equal.  I would rather have a potentially fraught basis for my decision than just pick one at random.
